article_text:
The IUD is making a comeback more than 30 years after a generation of women was scared away from the birth-control device by the faulty Dalkon Shield.

This year, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved Bayer HealthCare Pharmaceuticals' Skyla, the first new intrauterine device on the market in 13 years. Planned Parenthood has launched a nationwide campaign in its clinics promoting a copper IUD as the most effective form of emergency contraception. And in New Orleans, three-year-old startup Bioceptive Inc. is...

twitter.description: A device more effective than birth-control pills in typical use seeks a new market of younger women, a better insertion method and a way to get past misinformation.
twitter.title: A Birth-Control Comeback: The IUD

image.alt: What is 20 times more effective than birth control pills?
